focus_skills: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
Inference from sample statistics and margin of error

questions.question: In a triangle, the measures of two angles are 55° and 65°. What is the measure of the third angle?
questions.explanation: The sum of the interior angles in a triangle is 180°. Subtract the given angles: 180° - 55° - 65° = 60°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that the sum of angles in any triangle is always 180°; use this to find missing angles quickly.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='300' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='100' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='310' y='255' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='80' y='270' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='95' y='40' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two line segments intersecting at point B. Segment AB is horizontal extending to the right, and segment BC is vertical extending upwards.
questions.question: In the figure, line segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></math> is horizontal, and line segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover></math> is vertical, intersecting at point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math>. What is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line and a vertical line intersect to form a perpendicular angle, which measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>90</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='300' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='100' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='310' y='255' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='80' y='270' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='95' y='40' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><polyline points='100,230 120,230 120,250' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='130' y='225' font-size='14' fill='red'>90°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The figure with a red square symbol at vertex B indicating a 90-degree angle.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall that the intersection of horizontal and vertical lines creates perpendicularity, which is always <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>90</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.

questions.question: Solve for <math><mi>x</mi></math>: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.explanation: Add 12 to both sides: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations step by step.

questions.question: A straight line has an angle of 180°. If one angle measures 75°, what is the measure of the adjacent angle in degrees?
questions.explanation: Adjacent angles on a straight line sum to 180°: 180° - 75° = 105°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Adjacent angles on a straight line are supplementary, summing to 180°.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='240' y1='50' x2='160' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M205 100 A 30 30 0 0 1 228 80' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='190' y='90' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>p</text><path d='M165 200 A 30 30 0 0 1 188 180' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='150' y='190' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>q</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two parallel horizontal lines intersected by a slanted transversal line. Angle p is located at the top intersection in the upper-left position. Angle q is located at the bottom intersection in the upper-left position.
questions.question: In the figure, two parallel lines are intersected by a transversal. If the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>p</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>110</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, what is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>q</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Angles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>p</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>q</mi></math> are corresponding angles because they are in the same relative position at each intersection. Since the lines are parallel, corresponding angles are equal. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>110</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='240' y1='50' x2='160' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M205 100 A 30 30 0 0 1 228 80' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='160' y='85' font-size='14' fill='red'>110°</text><path d='M165 200 A 30 30 0 0 1 188 180' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='120' y='185' font-size='14' fill='red'>110°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The figure with both corresponding angles highlighted in red and labeled as 110 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for F-shapes to identify corresponding angles. Corresponding angles are in the same position relative to the transversal and parallel lines.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe calls for 3 cups of flour for every 2 cups of sugar. If 9 cups of flour are used, how many cups of sugar are needed?
questions.explanation: The ratio is 3:2. Set up proportion: <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mi>s</mi></mfrac></math>. Solve: <math><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use cross-multiplication to solve proportions in ratio problems.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='100,250 200,131 300,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='145' y1='185' x2='155' y2='195' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='245' y1='195' x2='255' y2='185' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='80' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='195' y='120' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='310' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><path d='M130 250 A 30 30 0 0 1 125 235' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='125' y='245' font-size='12'>50°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: An isosceles triangle ABC with base AC. Tick marks on sides AB and BC indicate they are equal length. Angle A is labeled as 50 degrees.
questions.question: Triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is isosceles with <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. If the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, what is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, the triangle is isosceles with base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. The base angles opposite the equal sides are equal, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. The sum of angles in a triangle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>80</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='100,250 200,131 300,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><text x='80' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='195' y='120' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='310' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><path d='M130 250 A 30 30 0 0 1 125 235' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='110' y='245' font-size='12'>50°</text><path d='M270 250 A 30 30 0 0 0 275 235' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='260' y='245' font-size='12' fill='red'>50°</text><path d='M190 145 Q 200 160 210 145' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='190' y='165' font-size='12' fill='red'>80°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangle ABC showing that base angle C is also 50 degrees, and the vertex angle B is calculated to be 80 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember: Base angles of an isosceles triangle are always equal. If you know one base angle, you know the other.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math> can be expressed as <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, so a + b = 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To factor quadratics, find two numbers that multiply to the constant term and add to the linear coefficient.

questions.question: In a right triangle, the opposite side to a 30° angle is 5 units. What is the length of the hypotenuse? (Enter as an integer or decimal.)
questions.explanation: In a 30-60-90 triangle, hypotenuse is twice the shorter leg: 2 × 5 = 10.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize special right triangle ratios for 30-60-90: sides 1 : √3 : 2.

questions.question: A item's price is increased by 20%, then decreased by 20%. What is the net percentage change?
questions.explanation: Assume $100. Increase: $120. Decrease: $120 × 0.8 = $96. Net: -4%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Successive percentage changes are not additive; calculate step by step.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='240' y1='50' x2='160' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='220' y='120' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>s</text><text x='195' y='190' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>r</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two parallel horizontal lines intersected by a transversal slanting from top-right to bottom-left. Angle r is the interior angle on the right side of the transversal at the bottom intersection. Angle s is the interior angle on the right side of the transversal at the top intersection.
questions.question: In the figure, the lines are parallel, and the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>65</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. What is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>s</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Angles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>s</mi></math> are consecutive interior angles (same-side interior angles). When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, consecutive interior angles are supplementary (add up to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>). Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mn>65</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>115</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='240' y1='50' x2='160' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M228 100 A 30 30 0 0 1 214 120' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='225' y='120' font-size='14' fill='red'>s=115°</text><path d='M195 200 A 30 30 0 0 1 188 180' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='200' y='195' font-size='14' fill='red'>r=65°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The figure with angle r labeled 65° and angle s labeled 115°, showing they are consecutive interior angles.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify 'Consecutive Interior Angles' (inside the parallel lines, on the same side of the transversal). Unlike alternate interior angles, these sum to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: Solve the system: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>? (Enter as an integer.)
questions.explanation: Multiply the first equation by 2: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. Subtract the second: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>-</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mn>24</mn> <mo>-</mo> <mn>2</mn></math>, so <math><mn>11</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use elimination by making coefficients match for one variable.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 350,250 200,124' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='124' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='120' y1='180' x2='135' y2='195' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='265' y1='195' x2='280' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='30' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><text x='360' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>E</text><text x='195' y='110' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>F</text><path d='M80 250 A 30 30 0 0 1 75 235' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='85' y='245' font-size='14'>40°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: An isosceles triangle DEF with a wide base DE. A dashed line descends from vertex F to the center of the base. Tick marks on sides DF and EF indicate equal length. Angle D is labeled 40 degrees.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math>, angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>40</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, and the line from <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>F</mi></math> bisects the base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi></math>. If the triangle is isosceles with <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math>, what is the measure of the angle at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>F</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Because the triangle is isosceles (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>F</mi></math>), the base angles are equal. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>∠</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>40</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. The sum of angles in a triangle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, so the vertex angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>40</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>40</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>100</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 350,250 200,124' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='124' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='1' /><text x='30' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><text x='360' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>E</text><text x='195' y='110' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>F</text><text x='85' y='245' font-size='14'>40°</text><path d='M320 250 A 30 30 0 0 0 325 235' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='290' y='245' font-size='14' fill='red'>40°</text><path d='M180 140 Q 200 155 220 140' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='180' y='170' font-size='14' fill='red'>100°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The triangle with angle E labeled 40° (matching D) and the top angle F labeled 100°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a triangle is isosceles, the angles opposite the equal sides are always equal. This is often the first step in solving for missing angles.

questions.question: Solve for x and y: <math><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>. What is <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Divide the equations: <math><mfrac><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac> <mo>/</mo> <mfrac><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>y</mi></mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mn>16</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>32</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, simplifying to <math><mi>y</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. So y = x/2. Substitute into first: <math><mi>x</mi> <mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <mn>16</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup> <mo>/</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>16</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <mn>64</mn></math>, x=4, y=2, xy=8.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For nonlinear systems, divide or substitute to simplify.

questions.question: A circle has equation <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Standard form <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so r=5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize the standard equation of a circle to identify center and radius.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A survey of 100 people has a margin of error of ±4%. If 52% favor an issue, what is the lower bound of the confidence interval? (Enter as decimal.)
questions.explanation: Lower bound: 52% - 4% = 48%, or 0.48.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Margin of error defines the range around the sample statistic.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='350' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='60' y1='248' x2='340' y2='52' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='240' y='140' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>u</text><text x='160' y='120' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>v</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two intersecting lines forming four angles. Angle u is the acute angle on the right, and angle v is the adjacent obtuse angle on the left, forming a straight line.
questions.question: In the figure, the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>u</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>35</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. What is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>v</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Angles <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>u</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>v</mi></math> form a linear pair on a straight line. Angles in a linear pair are supplementary, meaning they add up to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mn>35</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>145</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='350' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='60' y1='248' x2='340' y2='52' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M230 150 A 30 30 0 0 1 225 132' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='240' y='140' font-size='14' fill='red'>35°</text><path d='M170 150 A 30 30 0 0 1 225 132' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='140' y='120' font-size='14' fill='red'>145°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The figure with angle u labeled 35° and angle v labeled 145°, showing that together they complete the straight line (180°).
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify linear pairs: adjacent angles formed by intersecting lines always sum to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor numerator: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, denominator: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Factor numerators and denominators to simplify rational expressions.

questions.question: A cylinder has radius 3 cm and height 10 cm. What is its volume in cubic cm? (Use π=3.14, round to nearest integer.)
questions.explanation: Volume = <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3.14</mn> <mo>×</mo> <mn>9</mn> <mo>×</mo> <mn>10</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>282.6</mn> <mo>≈</mo> <mn>283</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall volume formula for cylinder: πr²h.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='100,250 150,100 250,150 300,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><text x='90' y='270' font-size='12'>W=50°</text><text x='270' y='150' font-size='12'>Z</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Quadrilateral with angles W=50°, Z to find.
questions.question: In the quadrilateral, opposite angles sum to 180°, angle W is 50°. What is angle Z?
questions.explanation: If cyclic or supplementary, Z = <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo> <mo>-</mo> <mn>50</mn><mo>°</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mn>130</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='100,250 150,100 250,150 300,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><text x='90' y='270' font-size='12'>W=50°</text><text x='270' y='150' font-size='12'>Z=130°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Quadrilateral with angles W=50° and Z=130° labeled.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For certain quadrilaterals, opposite angles are supplementary.
